A set is a collection of distinct objects considered as an entity.

Given a commutative ring R, the polynomial ring R[X] is the set of all sequences (a_i) where a_i in R and a_i=0 for almost all i, equipped with addition and multiplication defined by (a_i)+(b_i)=(a_i+b_i) and (a_i) 
cdot (b_i)=(c_i) where c_i=
sum_{
u+
u=i} a_
u b_
u. Elements of R[X] can be written as 
sum_{i=0}^n a_i X^i where X is the sequence (0,1,0,0,...).
Does the concept of a/an Set need to be defined for a definition of a/an Polynomial Ring to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: To define a polynomial ring R[X], the definition explicitly uses the concept of a set. It describes R[X] as the set of all sequences (a_i) where each a_i is an element of R and almost all a_i are zero. This definition inherently relies on the concept of a set as it involves the collection of sequences, each treated as an object, forming a whole entity (the ring R[X]). Without the concept of a set, the notion of collecting these sequences into a whole entity, which is fundamental to the structure of a polynomial ring, would not be possible. Therefore, the concept of a set is necessary to properly define what a polynomial ring is, as it provides the framework for understanding and organizing the elements (sequences) of the ring.
